# Discord Channel Analysis: üíª‚îÇdevelopers

## 1. Summary
The discussion in the developers channel primarily focused on UI development in the Hyperfy platform. A key technical conversation revolved around creating full-screen UI elements and accessing viewport dimensions. User shmoji inquired about obtaining screen width/height for screen space UI, which led to multiple solutions being shared. 0mka provided a code snippet demonstrating how to create a full-screen UI using app.control() to access screen dimensions. Ashxn mentioned plans to add world.viewportWidth and world.viewportHeight properties and later shared a GitHub PR link (#109). 

Other technical topics included a brief mention of client-side/server-side challenges, loading remote GLB models with rigidbodies and colliders, and work on animation layers for features like gun mechanics. There was also a note about a Safari-specific issue where UI elements outside the overflow area cause browser refreshes, highlighting cross-browser compatibility concerns.

The conversations demonstrate collaborative problem-solving among community members, with experienced developers offering solutions and planning platform improvements based on user needs.

## 2. FAQ
Q: How do I get screen width/height in a Hyperfy app for screen space UI? (asked by shmoji) A: You can use screen.width, screen.height or access them via app.control() (answered by 0mka and Ashxn)
Q: Can we load an app using world.load()? (asked by .hyp shaman) A: Not apps, but you can use this to load GLBs from remote sources (answered by Ashxn)
Q: Is there a way to make a UI "fill the entire screen"? (asked by shmoji) A: Yes, by using app.control() to get screen dimensions and setting appropriate UI parameters (answered by 0mka)

# Discord Chat Analysis for üßä‚îÇ3d-design Channel

## 1. Summary
The chat segment contains a brief discussion about 3D design challenges in Hyperfy environments. Fibelius mentions struggling with a v1 world containing Kitbash 3D buildings and inquires about v2 compatibility and whether purchasing the Kitbash Neo Tokyo kit would be worthwhile for a non-professional designer. hiroP responds with technical advice about Kitbash's new "game ready" kits, noting they're optimized for Unreal Engine with fewer draw calls and optimized meshes/textures, but still have high poly counts focused on Nanite technology. hiroP warns that Kitbash models would require significant optimization work to run smoothly in Hyperfy and suggests alternatives: looking for low-poly assets on platforms like Fab or Artstation, or creating low-poly versions of Kitbash models and projecting textures onto them. Fibelius clarifies their interest in architectural models rather than dystopian cities, mentioning previous work with Alvar Aalto's Villa Mairea. hiroP recommends checking futuristic sculptural buildings from Kitbash and suggests exploring Untitled's MOCA builds, which are CC0-licensed.

## 2. FAQ
Q: How long until v2 is available in HQ? (asked by Fibelius) A: Unanswered
Q: Is it worth buying the Kitbash Neo Tokyo 3D building Kit for a non-pro 3D designer to build in Hyperfy? (asked by Fibelius) A: Kitbash models will be difficult to optimize for Hyperfy due to high poly counts and textures, but could work with significant effort. Consider low-poly alternatives or texture projection techniques. (answered by hiroP)
Q: Is v2 significantly different from v1? (asked by Fibelius) A: Unanswered
